text:
Hello <@UJJMT9ZNJ>, here's a strategy for you.

1. Go to <http://Ahrefs.com|Ahrefs.com>
2. Plug in your competitor in Site Explorer.
3. I went in & put <http://looka.com|looka.com>
4. Then, under backlinks, just filter via "ref" URLs
5. You will get all the websites and bloggers who are currently promoting <http://Looka.com|Looka.com>'s affiliate program.
6. You can reach out to them directly now & ask to sign up for yours

root.text:
Hi all!

I need some advice. I work with the marketing team at <http://LOGO.com|LOGO.com> and we’re trying to promote our partnerships (white-label and API) and affiliate program. I’ve already got email covered. What else can I do to reach out to people who might be interested in signing up? This is a new territory for me so I’ll appreciate any tips/advice I can get. :blush: I’ve got more details here: <https://logo.com/blog/logo-affiliate-program>

Happy to discuss and answer any questions. Thanks a lot!

attachments.fallback: LOGO.com Affiliate Program: Join And Get Rewarded! | LOGO.com
attachments.text: Earn money with one of the best high-paying affiliate programs. Earn flat commissions. Perfect for beginners and advanced.
attachments.title: LOGO.com Affiliate Program: Join And Get Rewarded! | LOGO.com

text:
If you were to join a mid-size SaaS company as their first content marketing specialist and your main role is to build a content marketing engine.

What would you focus on doing in your first month?

elements.text:
If you were to join a mid-size SaaS company as their first content marketing specialist and your main role is to build a content marketing engine.

What would you focus on doing in your first month?

text:
That's an easy one. I'd want to learn as much about the product and audience as possible.

So that means:
• spending time with the product folks
• listening to sales calls
• watching product materials
• reading product materials
• scoping out who we lose deals to
• talking to existing customers

elements.text:

talking to existing customers

text: From my experience. I think you could get by producing a set of talking head videos with a few animations or stills spending in the $2-5K range per video. We're looking at hiring someone in-house though because we want to scale video.

elements.text: From my experience. I think you could get by producing a set of talking head videos with a few animations or stills spending in the $2-5K range per video. We're looking at hiring someone in-house though because we want to scale video.

text: <@UJ94SJMG9> I’d also audit any existing content they have. See what the winners currently are with the audience and repurpose that stuff while you get your feet under you learning the product/audience.

elements.text: I’d also audit any existing content they have. See what the winners currently are with the audience and repurpose that stuff while you get your feet under you learning the product/audience.

text: I’d also start KW research and see what existing site is ranking for. But yeah, first 30 days all about understanding, 30-60 assess & prioritize your recos, 60-90 get into action (making sure you have some stuff in there that will drive faster results)

elements.text: I’d also start KW research and see what existing site is ranking for. But yeah, first 30 days all about understanding, 30-60 assess & prioritize your recos, 60-90 get into action (making sure you have some stuff in there that will drive faster results)

text: ^ love all of these answers. And as someone who has sat in this role, one of the most beneficial things for me was to have conversations with founders, product research team, customers, sales, etc. This can give you a wealth of information that you can easily turn into content. Good luck!

text:
Hi everyone, I started as content team lead at a new company last week, and I'm getting to know their current strategy and processes. I have a couple years of SEO experience (mostly on-page) but I'm out of practice since SEO wasn't a big part of my last role of two years.

I met with the company's SEO agency today and they explained that their link building strategy is to write high quality articles on "tangentially related" topics to our industry and then pitch the article to reporters and publishers for possible backlinks.

I'm all about publishing high quality, shareable content, but I'm hung up on the topics. The company is in the text message marketing industry, and some of the articles the agency has helped publish for link building were:

• How anti-social people are by state (this one _at least_ had the word text in it a couple of times, but not in context of marketing)
• Coffee drinking habits by state
I guess I just need a gut check. These topics are buzzy and do get links, but they aren't bringing in the right traffic. Is this a sound strategy, or should I push them to only write about things that are relevant to our audience?

elements.text:

I met with the company's SEO agency today and they explained that their link building strategy is to write high quality articles on "tangentially related" topics to our industry and then pitch the article to reporters and publishers for possible backlinks.

I'm all about publishing high quality, shareable content, but I'm hung up on the topics. The company is in the text message marketing industry, and some of the articles the agency has helped publish for link building were:
How anti-social people are by state (this one
at least
had the word text in it a couple of times, but not in context of marketing)
Coffee drinking habits by state

I guess I just need a gut check. These topics are buzzy and do get links, but they aren't bringing in the right traffic. Is this a sound strategy, or should I push them to only write about things that are relevant to our audience?

text: Sorry, I deleted my comment to add more context. If you start getting a ton of backlinks from sites that have nothing to do with your company, that’s not good. But I don’t think a few will hurt, as long as the actual links are relevant and the sites are high-quality.

elements.text: Sorry, I deleted my comment to add more context. If you start getting a ton of backlinks from sites that have nothing to do with your company, that’s not good. But I don’t think a few will hurt, as long as the actual links are relevant and the sites are high-quality.

text: It's not the worst strategy in the world, but it doesn't feel like it should be that hard to make interesting/link-worthy content about texting though...

elements.text: It's not the worst strategy in the world, but it doesn't feel like it should be that hard to make interesting/link-worthy content about texting though...

text:
My first response was a slight cringe. I agree with everything above — the high-DA backlinks are nice and can technically help, but they could potentially hurt if the relevancy of the site becomes muddy.

Like Eric said, that seems like a poor strategy with such a great/deep topic. There are a TON of topics that fit in that niche that are also very shareable, even just off the top of my head.

My personal response would be to ask for a pivot. Backlinks are great and I know they matter, but I've seen pretty awesome results when new businesses instead focus on really great, topical content. Of course, not all of it will be perfectly aligned (top of funnel content matters for a reason) but those two articles you sent just don't belong on the site IMO.

Also, as you pointed out, just because they bring in good links doesn't mean the traffic is relevant to what you're selling. I'd personally ask that they spend a lot less time with backlink outreach and move that time into content creation for awhile.

elements.text:
My first response was a slight cringe. I agree with everything above — the high-DA backlinks are nice and can technically help, but they could potentially hurt if the relevancy of the site becomes muddy.

Like Eric said, that seems like a poor strategy with such a great/deep topic. There are a TON of topics that fit in that niche that are also very shareable, even just off the top of my head.

My personal response would be to ask for a pivot. Backlinks are great and I know they matter, but I've seen pretty awesome results when new businesses instead focus on really great, topical content. Of course, not all of it will be perfectly aligned (top of funnel content matters for a reason) but those two articles you sent just don't belong on the site IMO.

Also, as you pointed out, just because they bring in good links doesn't mean the traffic is relevant to what you're selling. I'd personally ask that they spend a lot less time with backlink outreach and move that time into content creation for awhile.

text:
Rebekah's response triggered another higher-level reaction:

Every time I've felt like an agency was doing the wrong thing and I didn't say anything, I ended up regretting it later. If you're managing that agency, go with your gut and give them the feedback they need sooner rather than later.

elements.text:
Rebekah's response triggered another higher-level reaction:

Every time I've felt like an agency was doing the wrong thing and I didn't say anything, I ended up regretting it later. If you're managing that agency, go with your gut and give them the feedback they need sooner rather than later.

text: YES! 1000% agree with you, <@UUH2ESL66>. I've had that problem when I was in-house and failed to say something to an agency we brought in, and now running an agency I have ALWAYS preferred clients be upfront with me and just give candid feedback. Way better for developing a positive long-term relationship. (Plus, if they flat-out refuse and can't really support their responses, it gives you an idea of whether or not you should keep working together.)

elements.text: YES! 1000% agree with you,

. I've had that problem when I was in-house and failed to say something to an agency we brought in, and now running an agency I have ALWAYS preferred clients be upfront with me and just give candid feedback. Way better for developing a positive long-term relationship. (Plus, if they flat-out refuse and can't really support their responses, it gives you an idea of whether or not you should keep working together.)

text: Hey Dani! Jumping in to this thread here as I also work in the text message industry (more sales focused vs marketing focused) and I’m curious as to why their strategy would be on these topics vs the very sharable and highly searched SMS topics? The amount of ideas you could generate on relevant topics is basically endless. Curious if their ICP is within the small business/generally non tech savvy realm, so they’re hoping to go for volume vs product understanding and that’s where the strategy is coming from? I am by no means an SEO expert, but I’d be happy to offer some perspective/research from domain expertise if you need. You’ve gotten a lot of great advice here though!
